The CRISPR/Cas13 system could specifically bind and precisely cleave ssRNAs without 27 altering the host genome, providing a potential novel strategy against the foreign RNA viruses. In 28 this study, we aim to explore whether the CRISPR/Cas13d system can be used to inhibit the syndrome virus (PRRSV) as a model to test the hypothesis. Porcine reproductive and respiratory 31 syndrome (PRRS) caused by PRRSV is one of the most severe infectious diseases in the swine 32 industry, which leads to a huge economic loss worldwide (Chand et al., 2012; Zhou and Yang, 33 2010) . PPPSV is an enveloped, positive-strand RNA virus belonging to the Arteriviridae family in 34 the order of Nidovirales (Snijder et al., 2013) . 35 We constructed a reporter system to rapidly test the RNA cleavage efficiency of the 36 CRISPR/Cas13d system. The reporter vectors were composed of the mCherry fluorescence gene 37 fused with either PRRSV ORF4 or ORF5 under the control of a CMV promoter, with two nuclear 38 localization signals (NLSs) at the N-and C-termini of mCherry to localize the fusion proteins in the 39 nucleus ( Fig. S1A ). Seven 30-bp oligonucleotides, including one random sequence as the non-target 40 guide RNA (gRNA) control (NC-gRNA) and six gRNA sequences targeting ORF4 (ORF4-gRNAs) 41 or ORF5 (ORF5-gRNAs), were synthesized and cloned into gRNA-expression vectors, respectively 42 ( Fig. S1A ). The human codon-optimized Cas13d was synthesized and cloned into an expression 43 vector with two NLSs at its N-and C-termini and driven by the CMV promoter (named 44 NLS-Cas13d) (Fig. S1A) . A control vector containing a mutated Cas13d which lacks the 45 ribonuclease activity (named NLS-dCas13d) was also constructed ( NLS-Cas13d/ORF4-gRNAs was significantly decreased (Fig. 1A) . In this study, we focused on the antiviral capacity of the 120 CRISPR/Cas13d system and presented a new strategy for mammalian RNA virus interference. 121

Compared with the NLS-dCas13d/NC-gRNA control cells, the 127 NES-Cas13d/gRNA significantly knocked down the GFP-PRRSV expression in Marc145 cells 128 (decreased by 64% by NES-Cas13d/ORF4-gRNA1 and decreased by 58% by 129 NES-Cas13d/ORF5-gRNA1), while NLS-Cas13d/gRNA did not show significant viral RNA 130 cleavages. The viral titers of GFP-PRRSVs collected from the supernatant of NLS-Cas13d/gRNA 131 transfected cells were only slightly lower than those from the NLS-dCas13d/NC-gRNA transfected 132 group and the NC group (a pure negative control without transfection) (Fig. 1D-F). The possible 133 reasons are: 1) the ssRNA genome of PRRSV is replicated and transcribed in the cytoplasm; 2) 134 NLS-Cas13d proteins mature in the cytoplasm and then are localized in the nucleus; 3) the process 135 of viral RNA cleavage is short. The viral RNA cleavage efficiency of NES-Cas13d was not as high 136 as the reporter system, which might be due to the relatively low transfection efficiency and the low 137 viral titer. After knocking down the mCherry-ORF4/5 mRNA expression by NLS-Cas13d/gRNA, 138 we did not observe changes in the gene expression of the potential off-target endogenous genes and 139 the cell viability of Marc145 cells (Fig. S3), indicating that the CRISPR/Cas13d system used in this 140 study is safe for the host cells. 141 Currently, Cas13d may be the best RNA-targeting CRISPR enzyme for mammalian RNA 142 engineering. Like other Cas13 proteins, the Cas13d enzyme can efficiently target virtually any RNA 143 sequences without the need of a protospacer flanking sequence. A study has shown that Cas13d can be used to modulate the splicing of endogenous 148 transcripts without changing the host genome, and its size is small enough to fit within the 149 packaging limit of AAV for in vivo delivery (Konermann et al., 2018). AAV can be one of the 150 suitable ways to package, deliver, and express the CRISPR/Cas13d system for targeting RNA 151 viruses in vivo in clinical trials of gene therapies in the near future. The life cycles of both RNA 152 viruses and DNA viruses both require the RNA stage, the CRISPR/Cas13d system may be a feasible 153 and efficient way for eukaryotic cells to defend against both RNA viruses and DNA viruses. Our 154 results demonstrated that Cas13d is suitable for RNA virus inhibition, and it may be also a potential 155 tool for DNA virus interference. Though CRISPR/Cas13d system is a potential tool for RNA 156 virus inhibition, there still exits several resistances, such as the work mechanisms of the 157 CRISPR/Cas13d system, how to ascertain the effective time of Cas13d, and how to deliver the 158 CRISPR/Cas13d to the target cells when RNA viruses infect host. 159In summary, we first reported the use of Cas13d for the highly efficient interference of 160PRRSVs. These results demonstrated that the CRISPR/Cas13d RNA cleavage system may serve as 161 a feasible and efficient tool for eukaryotic cells to defend against RNA viruses. A: mCherry expression in HEK293FT cells transfected with mCherry-ORF4, NLS-Cas13d, and ORF4-gRNAs (upper panel) or mCherry-ORF5, NLS-Cas13d, and ORF5-gRNAs (lower panel). NLS-Cas13d, Cad13d with two nuclear localization signals (NLSs) at its N-and C-termini; NLS-dCas13d, a mutated Cas13d lacking the ribonuclease activity and carrying two NLSs at its N-and C-termini two; NC-gRNA, non-targeting gRNA. B: Relative expression of mCherry-ORF4/5 mRNA in HEK293FT cells co-transfected with the mCherry-ORF4/5, NLS-Cas13d, and ORF4/5-gRNAs. C and D: GFP expression (C) and relative mRNA expression of PRRSV-ORF4 and PRRSV-ORF5 (D) in Marc145 cells at 48 h after the infection by GFP-PRRSVs. Marc145 cells were first transfected with various engineered Cas13d constructs and gRNAs for 12 h. GFP-PRRSVs at a MOI (Multiplicity of infection) of 0.01 were used for the infection. NES-Cas13d, Cad13d with two nuclear export signal (NESs) at its N-and C-termini; GFP-gRNA, a gRNA containing a 30-bp sequence targeting GFP; NC, a pure negative control without transfection. E and F: Detection of viral titers in the cell culture supernatants at different time points after GFP-PRRSV infection (at a MOI of 0.01) of Marc145 cells which were first transfected with the Cas13d constructs and PRRSV-ORF4-gRNA1 (E) or PRRSV-ORF5-gRNA1 (F).
